Award.AwardTitle: Theoretic Studies in Geophysical Fluid Dynamics and Climate Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal investigator develops and studies mathematical models of geophysical processes important for weather and climate. A major aim is to better understand sources of climate variability and the extent of their influences. The work involves new mathematical theory and techniques for dynamic transitions between states of a system described by a set of partial differential equations, and for memory effects -- differences in any particular state's features that depend on the chain of states through which the system arrives at that state. The system may be deterministic or stochastic. The mathematical issues are motivated by climate problems, and in turn the theory and the techniques are applied to the understanding of fundamental issues in climate dynamics and prediction. This project leads to improved predictions and new insights into weather, climate, and environmental phenomena of central importance to our economy. One such phenomenon to be studied in this project is the El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO), which is the dominant mode of inter-annual climate variability, and which has global impacts on temperature, precipitation, tropical cyclones, human health, and even conflict. The project involves scientists as well as graduate students from the related scientific disciplines. Graduate students are included in the work of the project.

The principal investigator and his collaborators work on dynamic transition theory for both deterministic partial differential equations and stochastic partial differential equations (SPDEs), and on developing theory and methods to establish effective non-Markovian reduced models for SPDEs. The goal is to quantify the sensitivity and dynamic transitions associated with typical sources of climate low frequency variability. Major goals include quantifying the role played by the memory effects, and identifying the key nonlinear interactions between low and high modes and the memory effects caused by noise. A few typical sources of climate variability that will be studied include ENSO, tropical convections, and the thermohaline circulations. Their variability, independently and interactively, may play a significant role in climate changes, past and future. The project involves specific collaborations with active atmosphere/ocean scientists in different institutions, and graduate students are included in the project work as well.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI and his collaborator Dr. Tian Ma have introduced a comprehensive and unified dynamic transition theory, resulting a general principle of dynamic transitions for dissipative systems, and to a unified theory for topological phase transitions. They have explored the physical implications of the theories applied to a range of problems in statistical and quantum physics, fluid dynamics, geophysical fluid dynamics, and astrophysics, including e.g. quantum phase transitions, the formation of solar surface eruptions and sunspots, critical exponents, boundary and interior separations of classical and geophysical fluid flows. We present here three examples of their discoveries.

First, in a recent paper [Tian Ma and Shouhong Wang, Quantum mechanism of condensation and high Tc superconductivity, International Journal of Modern Physics B,  33:14(2019); see also hal-01613117 (2017)], we discovered a new field theoretical interpretation of the wavefunctions in quantum mechanics (QM). More precisely the wave function is the common wave function for all particles in the same class determined by the external potential V, the square of the modulus of the wave function represents the distribution density of the particles, and the gradient of phase of the wave function provides the velocity field of the particles. This new interpretation of wave functions does not alter the basic theories of quantum mechanics, and instead offers new understanding of quantum mechanics, and plays a fundamental role for the quantum theory of condensed matter physics and quantum physics. We note that the classical interpretations by e.g. Niels Bohr and Albert Einstein require that the particle and its wavefunction are inseparable. In the new interpretation, the wavefunction is a field dictated by the external field V, and is detached/independent of the particle. This removes the absurdities and confusions surrounded with the Einstein-Bohr debate in quantum mechanics. 

Second, the PI and Dr. Ma discovered a fundamental first principle, potential-descending principle (PDP),  in statistical physics, demonstrating that the statistical physics is built upon two fundamental principles: the principle of equal a priori probability and the PDP. They show that PDP is the first principle for irreversibility for all thermodynamic systems, and the thermodynamic potential, rather than entropy, is the correct physical quantity for irreversibility. Basically, the thermodynamic potential is a higher level physical quantity than entropy, and consequently, is the correct physical quantity, rather than the entropy, for describing irreversibility for all thermodynamic systems. 

Third, in [Tian Ma and Shouhong Wang, Quantum mechanism of condensation and high Tc superconductivity, International Journal of Modern Physics B,  33:14(2019); see also hal-01613117 (2017)], they derive a quantum mechanism applicable to both high and low temperature superconductors. This is a longstanding problem, whose solution has impacts in designing advanced materials and quantum computers. The phenomenon of superconductivity was first discovered by Kamerlingh Onnes in 1911, in metallic mercury below 4K. Since then, the main goals of study have been  to attempt to observe superconductivity at increasing temperatures, and  to derive its physical mechanism.  The classical BCS theory (Bardeen-Cooper-Schrieffer, 1957) is a microscopic theory applicable to 35K or below superconductors.  Bednorz and Muller (1986) discovered superconductivity in a lanthanum-based cuprate perovskite material, which had a transition temperature of 35 K (Nobel Prize in Physics, 1987). Bednorz and Muller's work opened the door for high Tc superconductors. The current highest temperature of superconductors reaches 130K, and 160K under high pressure.

There are three main ingredients for the new quantum mechanism of high Tc superconductivity discovered by Dr. Ma and the PI. The first is the  field theoretical interpretation of quantum mechanical wave functions as discussed earlier. With this interpretation,  for superconductivity, the formation of superconductivity comes down to conditions for the formation of electron-pairs, and for the electron-pairs to share a common wave function.  The second ingredient is the layered PID (principle of interaction dynamics) interaction potential of electrons, modifying the classical Coulomb law. The third ingredient is the derivation of  both microscopic and macroscopic formulas for the critical temperature.
